metadata.case_name: Homi Jehangir Gheesta v. Commissioner of Income-tax

facts.text: M. H. Sanjana, maternal grandfather of the appellant, died on or about May 10, 1920.

Litigation between Sanjana's widow Cursetbai and daughter Bai Jerbanoo (appellant's mother) about validity of Sanjana's will; compromised, Bai Jerbanoo got one-third share in estate valued at about Rs. 9,88,000.
Bai Jerbanoo died in 1933, leaving husband Jehangirji (appellant's father), son Homi (appellant) and daughter Aloo; stated estate worth about Rs. 2,10,000 (no evidence thereof).
Appellant was minor at mother's death; had uncles Phirozeshaw (eldest) and Kaikhusroo; appellant's share of estate Rs. 70,000 taken charge of by Phirozeshaw and invested.
Phirozeshaw died on December 12, 1945; Kaikhusroo (executor) took charge, opened safe, found packet labelled with appellant's name containing high denomination notes of Rs. 87,500.

On January 24, 1946, appellant tendered notes for encashment; declaration: 'Legacy from my mother who died in 1933 when I was minor and money whereof was invested from time to time by my father and late uncle Phirozeshaw who recently died.'
Appellant submitted return showing nil income for 1946-47; in letter dated January 7, 1947, stated uncle Phirozeshaw handed over Rs. 87,500 to him and father before Phirozeshaw's death.
Affidavit before ITO on September 29, 1949, contained contradictory statements about handover.
ITO assessed appellant to income-tax on total income of Rs. 87,500 u/s 23(3) of Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, treating it as income from undisclosed source.
Appeal to Assistant Commissioner (AAC); statements of father and uncle taken; AAC upheld ITO.

Appeal to Tribunal; further statement of uncle Kaikhusroo; Tribunal noted discrepancies in declarations, letter, affidavit; held assessee failed to explain source, taxed as income; order October 7, 1955.
Appellant applied to Tribunal for reference u/s 66; refused March 8, 1956.
Petition to Bombay High Court u/s 66(2); summarily dismissed October 4, 1956.
Special leave granted by Supreme Court December 3, 1956 from High Court order.
Bai Aloo (sister) received Rs. 85,000 from uncle Phirozeshaw before his death; submitted return but no assessment.
Father summoned June 23, 1950 but failed to comply initially; later examined February 8, 1952.

legal_issues.text: Whether the order of the Tribunal dated October 7, 1955, on the face of it raised any question of law for reference under s. 66(2) of the Income-tax Act, 1922?
Whether Tribunal's decision was vitiated by considering irrelevant material, partly relevant/irrelevant material, or basing on conjectures, surmises and suspicions?

petitioner_arguments.text: Tribunal considered irrelevant material e.g. why uncle did not hand over money to Bai Aloo in 1939 or 1944; her statement showed she received Rs.85,000 without assessment.
Father's failure to comply with summons on short notice should not be used against appellant.
No explanation why uncle managed funds when father alive; but Tribunal prejudiced by remark on student earning in Bombay despite certificates.
Even if explanation rejected, Department must prove by direct evidence it was income.

court_reasoning.text: Tribunal's consideration of Bai Aloo's money not handed over when major/married was relevant to probability of story about shares from mother's estate.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Relevant for judging probability; non-assessment of Aloo does not make story probable.

court_reasoning.text: Father's summons non-compliance not vitiating; he was later examined.
Query why father effaced in management relevant; should have explained in statement.
Student status till 1950 irrelevant to source from mother's estate in 1945; no evidence of mother's estate value or investments increasing Rs.70,000 to 87,500.
Tribunal order read as whole shows fair consideration; not vitiated by defects in Dhirajlal or Omar Salay; no sentence-by-sentence microscope needed.
Rejection of explanation where circumstances infer income as only proper inference; inference of fact, not law; no need for direct evidence.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Department not required to prove by direct evidence.

holdings.text: No question of law arose from Tribunal's order; High Court right in summarily rejecting petition u/s 66(2).
Where assessee fails to explain source and circumstances warrant, amount treated as income from undisclosed sources.

precedents_cited.case_name: Dhirajlal Girdharilal v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: Principles on when Tribunal's decision raises question of law: irrelevant material, conjectures etc.

precedents_cited.case_name: Omar Salay Mohamed Sait v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: Similar to Dhirajlal; order not to be examined sentence by sentence.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Assessment u/s 23(3) as undisclosed income; reference to High Court u/s 66(2)

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, holding no question of law arose from Tribunal's order and no grounds to interfere with Bombay High Court's dismissal of petition u/s 66(2).

key_quotes.text: "We have, in these circumstances, no hesitation whatever in holding that the assessee has miserably failed to explain satisfactorily the source of the sum of Rs. 87,500. It is properly taxed as income."
key_quotes.speaker: tribunal

key_quotes.text: "Such an inference is an inference of fact and not of law."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Treating amount as income upon rejection of explanation

key_quotes.text: "We must make it clear that we do not think that those decisions require that the order of the Tribunal must be examined sentence by sentence, through a microscope as it were..."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Limits scrutiny of Tribunal order for question of law
